text.0: The NEJM Race and Medicine topic page features a selection of NEJM articles on race and medicine with implications for improving patient care, professional training, research, and public health. All articles assembled on the page are freely available.
text.1: The CDC has shortened the minimum amount of time people have to quarantine after a potential #COVID19 exposure from 14 days to as few as 7 days as long as the person is symptom free and tests negative.
text.2: Anticholinergic medications increase the risk for #MildCognitiveImpairment in cognitively normal adults: https://t.co/7V4mD9cmbw https://t.co/zeLe6sPdkC
text.3: World Health Organization expert groups recommended mortality trials of four repurposed antiviral drugs — remdesivir, hydroxychloroquine, lopinavir, and interferon beta-1a — in patients hospitalized with #COVID19. #SARSCoV2
text.4: We can address important #COVID19 control needs with continued follow-up of placebo recipients in phase 3 vaccine trials, use of placebo controls in large, simple safety trials, and clinical data from randomized trials evaluating new vaccines. #SARSCoV2
text.5: In this randomized, placebo-controlled trial in children age 5 and younger with severe anemia in a malaria endemic area, dihydroartemisinin–piperaquine administered after hospital discharge resulted in a lower incidence of readmission or death within 3 months after discharge.
text.6: Free Access: NEJM Covid-19 Articles and Resources. #COVID19 #SARSCoV2
text.7: This letter describes an immunocompromised patient who had persistent infection with SARS-CoV-2 over a period of months, despite several courses of remdesivir. Phylogenetic analysis showed accelerated viral evolution.
text.8: In this audio interview conducted on December 2, 2020, the editors discuss the WHO’s Solidarity study and the changing recommendations for the care of hospitalized patients.
